title: Successes, Failures and Learning From Them
segmentation: University and will discuss the topics that were set up like the failures, successes and what to do next, so.
Our failures, I think our for our community has been extremely successful and maybe the the only failure we could I could figure out is a non technical.
We are not doing as much public relations as we could.
We could be doing so I think this is cause we're too modest maybe and there are a lot of successes that that are appearing on national TV.
There was a program on documentary on TV about the SAS company, how successful and how well it treats its employees.
David Heckerman, in his keynote speech at the 2004 he mentioned the algorithms or which we're working on.
DNA from cancer and how they were able to figure out better drugs for cancer.

They don't want to publicize about them so that they maintain the edge against their competitors.

Or successes that have appeared in the last 1015 years that the community has started forming.

I think the major successes that the original goal has been achieved, the three communities, databases, machine learning and statistics which are forming the core of KDD are now talking together and now collaborating and know each others tools reasonably well.
The other major successes that our field has done extremely good outreach.
So there are several of you are working with bioinformatics colleagues.
People with so from sociology on social networks, communication networks.
The electrical engineers with text information retrieval and natural language processing, recently game theory and economics on social networks and the web, and many, many other cases.
So the third part of the questionnaire that we were given is what should be the next steps I think.
The outreach is terrific and we should continue doing that and I'm sure we will continue doing that.
The the emphasis could we that we could do for the next decade could probably be on large scale data mining and scalability.
How to handle terabytes and petabytes of data.
And there are some already impressive results.
Google won the Arabic translation competition with a very simple algorithm, but because it was running on huge amounts of data they had collected, so the algorithm was.
Very simple, nothing, nothing to brag about, but but the results were extremely good.

Corso mentioned that scalability is important parallel and also comes to mind is a natural gold natural tool to help us handle petabytes of.

2003 and Article 2003 on Google said it has almost half a million processors.
Probably it's much much higher now.
And the net Yahoo is collecting fire has five petabytes of data.
Or if I read correctly with Sam's Keynote for his even the competition data set, Netflix data set is 2 gigabytes uncompressed.
And this is just a small sample of what Netflix actually has.
So the target is for our algorithms to scale up two terabytes.
Petabytes of data.
Here, here is the attempt.
We're doing a team you do to try to handle this challenge.
We're collaborating with people from electrical engineering and they're building the self star system, which for the moment has more than 200 nodes.
The goal is to store a whole petabyte, create a small data center so that we can try out our algorithms there.
One of the major issues as Carina Cortez mentioned in her keynote speech in SDM is power, power and cooling actually are.
Becoming very hard problems.

Very interesting problems and the goal of the system is to be self correcting, self monitoring, self tuning, becausw, no humans operating human operators can handle so many hundreds of nodes of machines possibly failing and possibly misbehaving, which creates wonderful two way opportune.
As we can data mining our data mining tools can help can help this infrastructure by letting it learn.
Let it observe itself.
Observe the CPU utilization, the network traffic, that room temperature and try to predict disk failures so that they know that is going back track.
They know that it's going to fail, could notify its neighbors so that.
So that they it offloads its load to them and the other way around.
We could use us in data mining.
We could use such infrastructures to help us handle multiple terabytes.
To petabytes of data.
So these are the conclusions they only failure I see is that we are too modest and we don't brag enough.
Success is stunning.
Outreach to fascinating community like by informatics and social networks and streams and sensors.
And the next steps are scalability.
The most challenging problem is scalability.
For the next decade.
That's the end of the presentation.
